translated: Jātaka🔽The Minor Collection🔽The Chapter with Pairs
The Jātaka of the Moon-Goddess Kinnarī
“I think this is being brought near,
the moon that reddens with passion;
Today I give up my life,
my life-breath stops in the moon.
My heart sinks with suffering,
I burn and am consumed;
Because of your grief and sorrow,
not because of other sorrows.
I wither like grass and forest,
I dry up like an incomplete river;
Because of your grief and sorrow,
not because of other sorrows.
Like rain on a sore on the foot,
these tears flow from me;
Because of your grief and sorrow,
not because of other sorrows.”
“You are wicked, prince,
you who rejected the husband I wanted for you;
You pierced him in the forest,

translated: he lies there wounded.🔽Let the prince take away🔽this grief of my heart,

“Do not weep, Canda,

“I will surely die,

“I praise you, O Ayira Brahma,
who have given me the husband I desired;
You have sprinkled me with nectar,
I have come together with my beloved.
Now we will wander through the mountains, forests, and rivers,
with their streams strewn with flowers;
with their various woods,
speaking affectionately to each other.”
The Candakinnara Jātaka is the second.
